title: 113_s1231
content: The Duplication Elimination Act of 2013 may be cited as the Act. It includes expedited consideration of GAO recommendations in Title II of a joint resolution. The Duplication Elimination Act of 2013, also known as the Act, includes provisions for the submission of a proposed bill within 90 days of the GAO report publication. The bill must make legislative changes based on GAO recommendations and transfer any resulting savings to the Treasury's General Fund to reduce the deficit. The Duplication Elimination Act of 2013 requires the President to send a special message to Congress with a proposed joint resolution within a year of the GAO report publication. The message must detail recommendations excluded from the resolution, reasons for exclusion, and recommendations included in the resolution. The message is to be submitted to the Senate Secretary or House Clerk if the respective chamber is not in session. The President must make a special message and proposed joint resolution publicly available. The resolution will be introduced in the Senate and House on the next legislative day by the majority leader or designated member. The joint resolution introduced in Congress by the majority leader is not referred to a committee, placed on the calendar immediately, and its motion to proceed is privileged and not debatable. If agreed to, the resolution remains unfinished business until disposed of. In the House of Representatives, a joint resolution is expedited for consideration, with points of order waived and 2 hours of debate divided equally. A motion to reconsider the vote is not allowed, and final passage must occur within ten days. In the Senate, consideration of a joint resolution is limited to 10 hours, divided equally between majority and minority leaders. Further debate can be limited, and certain motions are not allowed. Passage of the joint resolution must occur immediately after proceeding to it. The Senate limits consideration of a joint resolution to 10 hours, divided equally between majority and minority leaders. Passage must occur immediately after the debate, with a vote within ten days of introduction. Appeals on procedural rulings are decided without debate. Points of order in the Senate or House are addressed promptly. In the Senate or House of Representatives, a Member may raise a point of order on a joint resolution's definition. Joint resolutions are not subject to amendment and are promptly considered by the other house without referral to a committee. The House follows specific procedures when receiving a joint resolution from the Senate, with exceptions for revenue measures. This subsection is enacted by Congress. The subsection enacted by Congress outlines the rulemaking power in the Senate and House of Representatives regarding joint resolutions. It emphasizes that the rules can be changed by either House with full recognition of their constitutional right.
